sub_topic: Finding the inverse of a matrix
message_1:
Find the inverse of the following 2x2 matrix:

$$\begin{bmatrix} 2 & 3 \\ 4 & 5 \end{bmatrix}$$
message_2:
To find the inverse of a 2x2 matrix, we can use the following formula:

$$A^{-1} = \frac{1}{\text{det}(A)} \begin{bmatrix} d & -b \\ -c & a \end{bmatrix}$$

where $A = \begin{bmatrix} a & b \\ c & d \end{bmatrix}$ and det(A) is the determinant of matrix A.

First, let's find the determinant of the given matrix:

$$\text{det}(A) = ad - bc = (2)(5) - (3)(4) = 10 - 12 = -2$$

Now, we can find the inverse of the matrix:

$$A^{-1} = \frac{1}{-2} \begin{bmatrix} 5 & -3 \\ -4 & 2 \end{bmatrix} = \begin{bmatrix} -\frac{5}{2} & \frac{3}{2} \\ 2 & -1 \end{bmatrix}$$

So, the inverse of the given matrix is:

$$\begin{bmatrix} -\frac{5}{2} & \frac{3}{2} \\ 2 & -1 \end{bmatrix}$$
